qas.question: What is one way a match can end?
What is one reason a draw can result?

answers.text: if both opponents are simultaneously disqualified

qas.question: What usually happens regarding a championship during a draw?

answers.text: may not change hands in the event of a draw

qas.question: What is another name for a one hour draw?

context: A professional wrestling match can end <a0_0>in a draw<a0_0/>. A draw occurs <a1_0>if both opponents are simultaneously disqualified<a1_0/> (as via countout or if the referee loses complete control of the match and both opponents attack each other with no regard to being in a match, like Brock Lesnar vs. Undertaker at Unforgiven in 2002), neither opponent is able to answer a ten-count, or both opponents simultaneously win the match. The latter can occur if, for example, one opponent's shoulders touch the mat while maintaining a submission hold against another opponent. If the opponent in the hold begins to tap out at the same time a referee counts to three for pinning the opponent delivering the hold, both opponents have legally achieved scoring conditions simultaneously. Traditionally, a championship <a2_0>may not change hands in the event of a draw<a2_0/> (though it may become vacant), though some promotions such as TNA have endorsed rules where the champion may lose a title by disqualification. A variant of the draw is the time-limit draw, where the match does not have a winner by a specified time period (a one-hour draw, which was once common, is known in wrestling circles as a <a3_0>"Broadway"<a3_0/>).
